raw_text:
Broadband takes on TV viewing
 
 The number of Europeans with broadband has exploded over the past 12 months, with the web eating into TV viewing habits, research suggests.
 
 Just over 54 million people are hooked up to the net via broadband, up from 34 million a year ago, according to market analysts Nielsen/NetRatings. The total number of people online in Europe has broken the 100 million mark. The popularity of the net has meant that many are turning away from TV, say analysts Jupiter Research. It found that a quarter of web users said they spent less time watching TV in favour of the net
 
 The report by Nielsen/NetRatings found that the number of people with fast internet access had risen by 60% over the past year.
 
 The biggest jump was in Italy, where it rose by 120%. Britain was close behind, with broadband users almost doubling in a year. The growth has been fuelled by lower prices and a wider choice of always-on, fast-net subscription plans. "Twelve months ago high speed internet users made up just over one third of the audience in Europe; now they are more than 50% and we expect this number to keep growing," said Gabrielle Prior, Nielsen/NetRatings analyst. "As the number of high-speed surfers grows, websites will need to adapt, update and enhance their content to retain their visitors and encourage new ones." The total number of Europeans online rose by 12% to 100 million over the past year, the report showed, with the biggest rise in France, Italy, Britain and Germany.
 
 The ability to browse web pages at high speed, download files such as music or films and play online games is changing what people do in their spare time.
 
 A study by analysts Jupiter Research suggested that broadband was challenging television viewing habits. In homes with broadband, 40% said they were spending less time watching TV. The threat to TV was greatest in countries where broadband was on the up, in particular the UK, France and Spain, said the report. It said TV companies faced a major long-term threat over the next five years, with broadband predicted to grow from 19% to 37% of households by 2009. "Year-on-year we are continuing to see a seismic shift in where, when and how Europe's population consume media for information and entertainment and this has big implications for TV, newspaper and radio," said Jupiter Research analyst Olivier Beauvillian.
llama3.2:1b: The number of Europeans with broadband internet access has increased by over 54 million people in the past year, according to Nielsen/NetRatings.
This growth is contributing to a decrease in TV viewing habits, particularly among those who are already connected to the web.
The report found that 40% of households with broadband have reduced their TV time due to faster internet access.
llama3.2:3b: 54 million Europeans have broadband access, up from 34 million last year, with the web eating into TV viewing habits, research suggests.
Broadband usage rose by 60% in Europe, with Italy seeing a 120% increase and Britain almost doubling its users over the past year.
The number of high-speed internet users has grown to over 50% of Europeans, threatening traditional TV viewing habits, with 40% of broadband households spending less time watching TV.
gemma2:2b: The number of broadband internet users in Europe has exploded over the past year, with almost 54 million people now hooked up to the net.
This increase is leading many Europeans to spend less time watching television in favor of online activities such as browsing websites and playing games.
Broadband access rose by 60% in the past year, driven by lower prices and wider choice of high-speed plans.
Jupiter Research suggests that this trend poses a major long-term threat to TV viewing habits, with broadband expected to increase from 19% to 37% of households by 2009.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The number of Europeans with broadband has increased, with the web taking over TV viewing habits.
Many users prefer to use their internet instead of watching TV, which is why there's a 12% increase in the total European population online.
The report suggests that broadband speeds have improved and are becoming more popular among people, as they offer faster internet browsing and downloading capabilities.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Broadband use in Europe surged over the past year, with 54 million people now accessing the web via high-speed internet compared to 34 million a year ago.
This growth led to decreased TV viewing habits among some users; 25% of those online spend less time watching television than before.

The trend is most pronounced in countries where broadband adoption has risen rapidly, notably the UK, France, and Spain, which are expected to see significant changes in media consumption as broadband penetration increases further.
qwen2.5:3b: Broadband usage among Europeans has increased significantly over the past year, from 34 million to 54 million, according to Nielsen/NetRatings.
This growth has led many people in Europe to spend less time watching TV and more time online, with a quarter of web users reporting reduced TV viewing due to internet access.
The report found that broadband usage increased by 60% over the past year, with Italy experiencing the largest jump (120%).
The study also revealed that the total number of Europeans online rose by 12% to 100 million over the same period, driven by lower prices and more subscription plans.
While television viewing habits are being challenged, TV companies face a significant long-term threat as broadband use is expected to grow from 19% to 37% of households by 2009.
opencoder:1.5b: The report argues that the growing prevalence of high-speed internet users is driving up the number of people online in Europe over the past year, which has resulted in a wider adoption of always-on, fast-net subscription plans by users.
Broadband also has raised the popularity of TV viewing habits, and many respondents have indicated they are spending less time watching TV than before.
However, it's important to note that this report does not provide specific data on how much each country had grown in the past year.
The growth rate for each country would need to be calculated based on the total number of people online at the beginning and end of 2021.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: The number of Europeans with broadband has surged significantly over the past year, reaching nearly 54 million, up from around 34 million before.
This growth, attributed to lower internet costs and always-on subscription plans, has led to a shift in television viewing habits.
According to market research firm Nielsen/NetRatings, half of online users prefer watching TV over the web, with a quarter reporting spending less time on TV for gaming or shopping.
The total number of Europeans online crossed the 100 million threshold, growing by 12% year-over-year, particularly in France, Italy, Britain, and Germany.
The shift to fast internet access has changed how people consume media online.
High-speed surfers now make up over 50% of European viewers, with growth expected to continue as the market grows.
However, despite this, traditional media like TV remains dominant in British and French households, driving changes in content consumption.
The rise in online shopping further influences TV viewing habits, offering new opportunities but also emphasizing the importance of traditional media for brand awareness and entertainment.
tinyllama:1.1b: The number of European households with broadband has exploded over the past year, with the web eating into TV viewing habits.
The report by Nielsen/NetRatings found that a quarter of people now use fast internet access for entertainment, up from 34 million in 2017.
This, in turn, has led to a significant shift in how people spend their leisure time in Europe.
According to Jupiter Research, broadband users are spending less time watching TV, with 54% of the population now on fast internet connections.
This is due to lower prices and a wider choice of always-on, fast-net subscription plans.
The study by analysts Nielsen/NetRatings found that, compared to last year, the number of people with broadband has nearly doubled in Italy and almost tripled in France.
Broadband users are also more likely to spend time on online games, which has led Jupiter Research to predict a major long-term threat for TV companies.
In the UK, where broadband has been increasing rapidly, 40% of people now say they are spending less time watching TV - suggesting that TV viewing habits may be changing for good.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The rapid growth of broadband internet usage is having significant effects on television viewing habits in Europe.

According to market research firm Nielsen/NetRatings, the number of people who are connected to the web via broadband has increased by over a quarter in just one year, from 34 million to over 54 million people.
These users spend more time watching TV in comparison to those without access to fast internet networks.

In Italy, for instance, there was a notable increase in the number of people who watch television on a regular basis, with around 120% of those surveyed admitting that they spend less time doing other activities such as browsing the web or playing online games.
This has led to an increased demand for fast internet access and an expansion of high-speed broadband subscription plans in Europe.

The rapid growth of broadband internet usage is driving significant changes in what people do in their spare time, with many opting for alternative activities such as browsing the web or playing online games.

In regions where broadband has increased the most, the impact on TV viewing habits can be particularly significant, with around a third of adults now spending more time watching television compared to those who have not experienced this level of accessibility.

Over the next five years, as broadband usage continues to increase, it is expected that these trends will become more pronounced and major implications for the media industry in terms of content availability, pricing and marketing strategies will arise.

This growth is changing what people do in their spare time, as many are turning away from TV to spend more time browsing web pages at high speed and downloading files such as music or films.
Jupiter Research's study suggested that broadband was challenging television viewing habits, with 40% of households with broadband spending less time watching TV.
The threat to TV is greatest in countries where broadband is on the up, such as the UK, France, and Spain.

The popularity of the internet has meant many are turning away from TV, say analysts Jupiter Research.
A quarter of web users said they spent less time watching TV in favor of the net, and this trend is expected to continue.
TV companies face a major long-term threat over the next five years due to the growing popularity of broadband.
hermes3:3b: Broadband usage in Europe doubled to over 54m people in last year, increasing TV viewing time online by 25% and challenging traditional TV habits.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Over the past 12 months, the number of Europeans with broadband has increased significantly, with just over 54 million people now connected to the internet via this means, a rise from 34 million a year ago according to market analysts Nielsen/NetRatings.
This growth in broadband users has led to TV viewing habits being disrupted as many consumers turn to the internet instead.
The increase in broadband users is largely due to lower prices and greater choice of fast-net subscription plans, with Italy seeing the biggest jump in numbers (up by 120%).
As more Europeans become connected through high-speed internet, websites are adapting their content to retain existing visitors and attract new ones.

This shift towards online entertainment has significant implications for traditional TV, newspaper, and radio industries, with Jupiter Research predicting that broadband is likely to grow from 19% to 37% of households by 2009.
In homes where broadband is available, 40% of consumers reported spending less time watching TV.

The total number of Europeans online has surpassed 100 million, with the biggest broadband growth in Italy and the UK.
Lower prices and more subscription options have driven this increase.
Analysts from Jupiter Research suggest that broadband is reducing TV viewing, with 40% of broadband users spending less time watching television.
This trend is strongest in the UK, France, and Spain, posing a long-term threat to TV companies as broadband adoption is expected to rise from 19% to 37% of households by 2009.
The shift in media consumption has significant implications for TV, newspapers, and radio.
stablelm2:1.6b: Broadband usage is gaining popularity over traditional TV viewing among Europeans, according to research by Nielsen/NetRatings.
The number of people with broadband has increased from 1 million to 2 million in a year, while the total number of online users reached 20 million.
This shift is attributed to lower prices and more choices for subscription plans.
As internet usage grows, websites need to adapt their content to retain visitors and attract new ones.
The study by Jupiter Research found that in homes with broadband, 25% spend less time watching TV, especially in the UK, France, and Spain.
This poses long-term threats to traditional media, as broadband is predicted to increase from 10% of households to 20% by 2049.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Broadband usage in Europe has significantly increased over the past year, with 54 million people now connected via broadband, a 60% rise from a year ago.
This growth is driven by lower prices and expanded fast-internet subscription plans.
As more Europeans gain access to high-speed internet, they're spending less time watching traditional TV.
Jupiter Research found that 40% of web users in such households reduced their TV viewing time.
The most substantial impact on TV viewing is observed in the UK, France, and Spain.
By 2009, broadband is expected to increase from 19% to 37% of households.
This shift has profound implications for traditional media like TV, necessitating that websites adapt their content to maintain visitors and attract new ones.
The total number of Europeans online rose by 12% to 100 million over the year.
